dimensions.name: Concept Clarity
dimensions.description: How clearly the teacher explains C operators (arithmetic, relational, logical, bitwise, assignment, etc.).
dimensions.examplesOfGood: Uses concise definitions; illustrates each operator with simple code snippets and explains the result step‑by‑step.
dimensions.examplesOfBad: Provides vague or ambiguous explanations; mixes operator categories without clear separation.

dimensions.name: Delivery & Communication
dimensions.description: Voice clarity, pacing, and engagement when presenting C operator concepts.
dimensions.examplesOfGood: Clear articulation; varies tone to emphasize precedence rules; maintains a steady pace allowing learners to follow code examples.
dimensions.examplesOfBad: Monotone delivery; speaks too quickly through complex expressions; uses excessive filler words.

dimensions.name: Content Structure
dimensions.description: Logical flow of the lesson: introduction → operator categories → syntax → examples → common pitfalls → summary.
dimensions.examplesOfGood: Starts with why operators matter, groups them logically, uses transitions, and ends with a recap of precedence and associativity.
dimensions.examplesOfBad: Randomly jumps between ++, &&, and |= without a clear order; omits a concluding summary.

dimensions.name: Student Engagement
dimensions.description: Interaction techniques that involve learners in practicing C operators.
dimensions.examplesOfGood: Poses quick quizzes (e.g., predict the output of `a += b << 2`), encourages students to write their own expressions, checks understanding with live coding.
dimensions.examplesOfBad: Delivers a one‑way lecture; never asks for predictions or checks if students grasp operator precedence.

dimensions.name: Accuracy
dimensions.description: Correctness of the information about C operators, including syntax, precedence, associativity, and side effects.
dimensions.examplesOfGood: All operator tables are correct; no misstatements about undefined behavior; examples compile and run as described.
dimensions.examplesOfBad: Incorrect precedence chart; claims `=` can be used as a comparison; provides code that contains compilation errors.
